results.title: The Pole vault
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Track and Field Instruction”.
Analyses the various skills required for pole vaulting; illustrates the forces involved in run up, hang, bar clearance, and throw away from the bar. Also shows how a beginner can organize training to achieve success.

results.title: The Point
results.creator_credit: Nilsson House Music, Murakami-Wolf Productions, Jerry Good, Larry Gordon, Harry Nilsson and Fred Wolf
results.brief_description: Based on a fable by Harry Nilsson, this delightful family film is set in the land of Point. In Point, every object, including people, is moulded into a point. Into this world little Oblio is born; the first and only roundheaded child in the town. Oblio and his dog, Arrow, are punished for having no point and are banished to the Pointless Forest. It is not as lonely as they imagined for in the forest they meet several other creatures who have also been exiled because they were different. Join Oblio and Arrow as they discover that you don’t have to have a point to be accepted. Narrated by Ringo Starr and animated by director Fred Wolf.

results.title: The Point
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, William Weintraub and Robert Duncan
results.brief_description: Point St. Charles is a notoriously bleak neighborhood in Montreal, considered to be one of the toughest in all of Canada. Many of the residents are English-speaking and of Irish origin living in a French speaking community; many of them are also on welfare. It is a district poor in terms of community facilities, high unemployment, lack of educational facilities and opportunities, and juvenile crime. Voice and narration by Budd Knapp.

results.title: The Pogles
results.brief_description: There was a program on British television in the sixties called Pogles’ Wood, which appeared on the BBC program ‘Watch with mother’, about old friends Mr and Mrs Pogle. This collection of six short animated puppet tales, ‘The Pogles’ is from the series that precedes Pogles’ Wood and tells the story of the magic plant and how the changling baby came to live with them in the woods. Originally screened only once on the BBC as it was deemed “too scary for afternoon TV” - (a funny thing to say about puppets really). This tape includes: ‘The Magic bean’, ‘A Silver crown’, ‘Pogle go home’, ‘A Flower for wishes’, ‘The Singing bird’, ‘King of the Fairies’. An enchanting collection of animated tales.

results.title: The Poetry Cup
results.creator_credit: Peter Lane, Ken Smeaton and Terrence Doran
results.brief_description: The inaugural Poetry Cup was filmed in September at the Rochester Castle Hotel, Fitzroy as part of the 1989 Spoleto Fringe Festival. Just as the comedy resurgence began in the small cafes and clubs before moving to a wider television audience so then the poets. These people are performers with an emphasis on entertainment. No quiet reads here, but full blooded performance poetry. Their skills have been honed amid beer, smoke, pool players and football, in the back rooms of inner city hotels such as the Provincial, the Rochester, the Leicester Arms and cafes, prisons, schools and the streets.

results.title: The Poetess Li Qing-Zhao = Li Qing Zhao
results.creator_credit: Xi'an Film Studio and Zhang Jinglong
results.brief_description:
The film presents a romanticized biography of one of China’s most famous poets, Li Qingzhao (AD. 1084-1155). The film begins with the young Li Qingzhao showing her poetry talent at a party for the so-called elites (scholars and government officials). Feeling jealous of Li’s talent, a scholar, Zhang claims that “ignorance is a virtue for women”. Another scholar, Zhao Mingcheng condemned this view and sang high praise of Li Qingzhao’s poetry. Li and Zhao got married and had a short and happy time together before Zhao left home for his archeology work. Around the year 1127, the Jurchens invaded the Hans and Li Qingzhao witnessed all the terrors of war as she went to look for her husband. However, Zhang, the one embarrassed by Li and her husband at the poetry party but now a senior official, tried all his best to prevent the couple reuniting. Li’s husband soon died and Zhao sent people to bribe Li to write complimentary poems for the decadent Song government, which Li refused. In Li’s later years, she completed the unfinished work of her husband and wrote many more famous poems. Li Qingzhao is perhaps China’s most famous poetess of all time. Many of her poems have become Chinese classical literature.

The film’s title character, Li Qingzhao, is played by China’s well-known actress XIE Fang, who starred in films such as Song of Youth (1959) and The Threshold of Spring (1962). (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; May 21, 2010)

results.title: The Plunder of peach and plum = Tao li jie [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Diantong Film Studio, Ma Dejian and Ying Yunwei
results.brief_description: China’s first talkie offers a grim picture of the fate awaiting young job-seekers in Shanghai society of the mid-1930s. An idealistic newlywed couple, recently graduated from university, find good white-collar jobs but both quit rather than submit to corruption and coercion in the workplace. However their desire to do the ‘right’ thing, takes them on a downward spiral which eventually leads to tragedy. The film is famous for a sequence which involves a single long tracking shot from an arriving taxi across the pavement, into and across a hotel lobby—an extraordinary feat for the time. Cast includes Yuan Muzhi and Chen Bo’er. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The Ploughman's lunch
results.creator_credit: Greenpoint Films, Simon Relph, Ann Scott and Richard Eyre
results.brief_description: Reporter James Penfield makes his money rearranging the facts, a talent he ruthlessly exploits in his friendship and love affairs. A political drama set against the backdrop of the Falkland’s crisis, the film takes a wry look at the Government’s attempt to justify the war. Set in the heartland of bourgeois England among media creators and academics, the personal, political and historical deceit of Thatcher’s Britain is ruthlessly exposed. Stars Jonathan Pryce and Tim Curry and features an astonishing climax as the crew and cast filmed undercover during the Conservative Party Conference.
